Description: Limestone relief of Iry: the slab is carved in fine low relief with a representation of Iry, wearing a leopard-skin and holding a staff and a sceptre. There are traces of black paint on Iry's wig which is of tight curls. He also wears bracelets, and around his neck hangs a curious leafy pendant strung between two beads. His musculature is carefully delineated, but his insteps are unnaturally arched. There are also five smaller representations of men, possibly sons of Iry: Nnk, Nfr-sšm-nsw, 'Iṯḥ, the scribe Kʒ(.i)-nfr and 'Iry-nḏs. The wig, eyebrow, eye, and pupil of the main figure are painted black; no other traces of colour remain.
Curator's comments: This slab has three companion slabs 1896,0511.10, 1896,0511.11, 1896,0511.12. Bibliography: B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' III (Oxford: Clarendon Press), p. 203; 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 58-59 No 10; G. Robins, ‘Proportion and Style in ancient Egyptian Art’ (Austin, 1994),p. 14, fig. 1.14.
Bibliographic references: James 1961 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc. Part 1 (pl.3)
Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (6)
Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.40-41)
